A monumental square in circular form. It creates beautiful visuals with the buildings forming a circular square around an equestrian statue of Louis XIV in the middle.  If you happen to pass by, I recommend you to pass through this square.
It's a plaza at a roundabout with a statue riding a horse in the center.

This square, which straddles the 1st and 2nd arrondissements of central Paris, is marked by the equestrian statue of Louis XIV, the Sun King. Here, a Victory Square was designed in the 17th century, with an equestrian statue of Louis XIV as its centerpiece. The equestrian statue was later destroyed, and the current statue was rebuilt in 1828. One of the highlights of this square is the magnificent Ottoman-style buildings that surround the circular square.
A nice square that has its own wonderful atmosphere early in the morning or at night. One of the many photogenic places in Paris.

Place des Victoires (Victory Square) is a square in Paris located on the border between the 1st and 2nd arrondissements. The scenographic square was created for Louis The statue was destroyed during the French Revolution, and was later restored by another (by Fran√ßois Joseph Bosio, 1828), which, it seems, does not have the optimal dimensions to harmonize with the surrounding buildings like the original one. Among the buildings, only those at numbers 4-12 are original. An Augustinian monastery once overlooked the square, although it was lost in the revolutionary fury, of which only the church of Notre-Dame des Victoires remains, built between 1629 and 1740 inspired by the Church of the Ges√π in Rome; inside it houses seven precious eighteenth-century canvases by Carl Van Loo.
Beautiful place. The statues which surrounded Louis 14 are at the Louvres.

Beautiful circular square with the equestrian statue of Louis XIV in the center. Beautiful facades around, luxury stores, bars/restaurants nearby. A few meters from the Louvre post office and buildings with interesting facades. A very pleasant neighborhood

Circular square, somewhat roundabout, surrounded by opulent buildings, with the statue of a victorious horseman in the middle, in accordance with its name  Located in the heart of Paris, it can be accessed from the Op√©ra Garnier district via rue du 4 Septembre, then along the Banque de France, one of whose entrances faces one of the streets leading to this square and giving a view above  To eat (subject to having the budget), there is a restaurant and a caf√©, still on the street linking Place des Victoires to the Banque de France

As I enter the Place des Victoires in Paris, I am immediately taken by the impressive symmetry and elegance of the square. Located in the middle of the city, surrounded by magnificent townhouses with classic facades, the square looks like a quiet monument to royal power and French history.  In the middle of the circular square stands the imposing equestrian statue of Louis XIV, the "Sun King". She towers majestically above everything, and I sense how the place is permeated with an aura of bygone royal splendor. The statue was erected in 1686 by sculptor Fran√ßois Girardon to honor Louis XIV and his military victories. It was a moment of triumph for the king, who wanted to radiate the power and splendor of the French Empire across Europe.  The square itself was designed by Jules Hardouin-Mansart, one of the most famous architects of the time. I can vividly imagine how the Parisian aristocracy once gathered here to show off the latest fashions and show off their presence near the royal court. Today the square has a quiet, almost contemplative atmosphere, but the harmony of the architecture remains a tribute to the glory days of absolutist France.  What particularly fascinates me is the story of the statue in the middle. The original statue, which showed Louis XIV on horseback, was destroyed during the French Revolution, when revolutionary forces began to overthrow everything associated with the Ancien R√©gime. The current statue, depicting the king in Roman armor, was erected in 1822, long after the revolution and upheaval that struck France. It's as if the city is still wrestling with its royal past - a monument that has been restored but can never be quite the same.  As I walk across the square, I see the elegant houses that surround the circle and I think of the aristocrats who once lived here. The facades, with their high windows and wrought iron balconies, bear witness to the time when Paris was the stage for Europe's major political and cultural events.  The Place des Victoires is not only an architectural masterpiece, but also a reflection of France's eventful history - from royal rule to revolutions and attempts at restoration. Today it is a quiet square in the heart of Paris, but when I look around I feel the deep-rooted history and constant change that this place has experienced. It is a place that tells of victories, but also of losses and changes.  As of: December 21, 2023

In the center of this square built in 1686, the statue represents King Louis XIV for whom the place was dedicated in honor of his military victories, the current statue dates from 1822 because the previous one was melted down during the revolution.  Place des Victoires is undoubtedly the least known of the 5 royal squares of Paris, probably because it is less imposing or majestic than its illustrious sisters Place Vend√¥me or Place de la Concorde.¬†Nevertheless, you will discover superb buildings typical of 17th century architecture (called Louis XIV style) as well as a general circular design which was a true architectural innovation at the time of its construction.

Discreet and yet sublime. This 17th century Place Royale, little known despite its privileged position in the heart of the capital, is one of the most beautiful vestiges of what architecture was like in the time of Louis XIV. Although major modifications were made to it, particularly in the 19th century, its soul endures. The setting for a monumental equestrian statue replacing the original pedestrian statue of the king, it is essential for a stroll in the 2nd arrondissement!
